journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part K: Journal of Multi-body Dynamics

title-group.article-title: Dynamic modelling and response analysis of closed high-speed press system

article-meta.aff: School of Mechanical Engineering, Southeast University, Nanjing, People’s Republic of China

author-notes.corresp: Fang Jia, School of Mechanical Engineering, Southeast University, 2# Southeast Road, JiangNing District, NanJing 211189, People’s Republic of China. Email: 13851896116@139.com

abstract.p: It is necessary to establish a dynamic model to predict and evaluate the dynamic performance of closed high-speed press system during design procedure, when it is impossible to carry out the test of prototype. In this work, a dynamic model for the closed high-speed press system is developed to predict and evaluate its dynamic performance. Unlike in previous models where the press frame is considered to be a single mass and the effects of the transmission mechanism and complex frame structure are neglected, the present model can be used to analyze the dynamic response of a multi-body vibration-impact system treating it as a coupled one. The simulation results reveal that the dynamic responses of press under piling condition include a transient impact and a free vibration process. The vibration acceleration and velocity curves of the upper beam of the closed high-speed press decrease with the increasing speed of rotation. In contrast, vibration acceleration and velocity curves of the lower beam of the press increase with the increasing rotation speed. The experimental results demonstrate that the dynamic model proposed herein is consistent with the actual working state of the closed high-speed press and the validity of the dynamic model is verified.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
The closed high-speed press, as ‘less/non-chip finish’ highly effective machine tool as well as one of the key industrial equipments, can manufacture metal parts closer to their final shapes and comply better to the requirements of clean and green production. Over time, with the continued development of technology, the speed of closed high-speed presses has been boosted remarkably. The design methodology has changed from traditional static design to dynamic design. In practice, common dynamic design is usually carried out by testing virtual prototypes and the design scheme is modified according to test results. This method is effective, but there are some problems with it:
it is difficult to modify the design scheme so that the modified scheme can be produced optimally.
it is time consuming and uneconomical to manufacture the virtual prototype.
it is difficult to ensure the similarity between the virtual prototype for test and final press product as a result of its complex structure.
Therefore, it is essential to establish a dynamic model to predict and evaluate the dynamic performance of a closed high-speed press system during the design process.

The main feature of a closed high-speed press system is the existence of a non-linear impact force generated through the interaction of the moulds during the pressing process. The non-linear force depends on the relative position and velocity of the interacting masses. This force will drastically change the entire distribution of the natural qualities of the system and transform the system into strongly non-linear one. Although the inertia force of the crank-slider mechanism in a closed high-speed press system has been reduced dramatically using a balance mechanism, the effect of the inertia force cannot be cancelled completely, especially when the press system is operated at high speeds, therefore, it is difficult to establish a dynamic model that can be used to analyze the dynamic response of a multi-body vibration-impact coupled system according to the real process, in which the effects of inertia force are taken into account.

Many researchers have studied the dynamic responses of high-speed presses. Chehab and El Naggar1,2 proposes the single-DOF and two-DOF mathematical models based on a press’s working state under different impact loads. Novak3–5 has studied the dynamics of hammer system equipped with a vibration isolator, with a focus on the modelling of the foundation system. Using the two-DOF mathematical model of punch, Chen and Liu6 have made a theoretical study of foundation vibration and noise in high-speed presses due to the initial sudden load and the sudden loss of load when a press punches through. In a recently published paper by the same authors,7 the authors present a mathematical model of non-linear combination disc-spring vibration isolator for high-speed press and explores the model’s dynamic responses under impact loads. In order to predict the dynamic response of working points under high-speed machining, Schmitz8 has determined the time domain response of assembly for a high-speed press. Schmitz connects the single vectors of the parts of the press using reacceptance coupling. In order to model the impact response of press machines accurately, Shimada and Shabana9 have proposed a new computational procedure in which a finite element floating frame of reference formulation is used. Lee10 has developed an ingenious varied-mass lumping method (VLM) fused with the percussion concept to integrate the dynamics analysis and design of press machine in a highly mutually beneficial sense. Nagamatsu and Sok-Chu11 explore the natural modes and corresponding frequencies of a C-type press using the component synthesis method and analyze the dynamic response using time–domain simulation analysis. To minimise the vibration of the high-speed press for better performance, Zhu et al.12 has studied the dynamic characteristics of main parts and combined structure of a high-speed press using ANSYS (FE analysis software). Kato13 and Naito14 present a method and device to control a press with low vibration and low noise and to create an appropriate control pattern. Li15 came up with a FE model for the frame of a J53-1600 double-disk friction screw press. The vibration responses of the press under cold stamping and forging were also simulated to provide rich references for the dynamic design of a friction press.

The above approaches to dynamic modelling of high-speed press system can be divided into two main categories: one where the lumped parameters method is used to establish the model, and one where dynamic modelling using finite element method (FEM) is used to establish the model. Both the single-DOF and two-DOF mathematical models available have an important role in the design and dynamic response analysis of the foundation system of a high-speed press; however, the single-DOF and two-DOF models neglect the influence of the press’s transmission mechanism and the complex frame structure and consider the press frame to be a single mass. Therefore, neither models can meet the dynamic design requirements for a closed high-speed press system. The FEM dynamic model can be used to simulate the complex structure of a closed high-speed press system, but results of the FE analysis inevitably contain simulation errors due to the complexity of contact surfaces. Furthermore, in all the previous models the impact load generated through interaction between moulds during pressing process is just simplify as rectangular or triangular shape of pulse load, while, actually, the non-linear impact load depends on the relative position and velocities of the interacting masses.

The primary objective of this work is to analyze the dynamic performance of a closed high-speed press system in a more reasonable and accurate way. In this article, the closed high-speed press system is considered to be as a multi-body vibration-impact system and a dynamic model is established for the closed high-speed press system by investigating a real system. In this dynamic model the transmission mechanism and multiple parts of the press frame were incorporated and used to analyze the dynamic response of the high speed. In addition, the Kelvin-Voigt model21,22 was used to model the collisions between the moulds and the components of the closed high-speed press frame. The dynamic performance of the press system was explored under operated condition.

This article is organised as follows: In Physical description section, the physical structure and principle of the closed high-speed press system is described briefly. In Foundation stiffness and damping section, the dynamic model is established. In Mathematical model section, the dynamic parameters of the dynamic model are determined. In Method of analysis section, the method of analysis is explained in details. In Results and discussion section, numerical simulations of the dynamic model are implemented and discussed, and the validity of the model is verified. Final section summarizes the proposed dynamic model and the conclusions as well as some suggestions for the future work.

sec.title: Physical description
sec.p:
The foundations of a closed high-speed press can be divided into two basic categories: foundations with inertial block (Figure 1(a) and (b)) and directly sprung machines (Figure 1(c)). Most press foundation configurations possess one or two vertical degree of freedom. When the press is rigidly connected to an inertial block built in soil, the type of foundation shown in Figure 1(a) may be considered to be a one degree of freedom foundation in the vertical direction. When the closed high-speed press is mounted on a foundation block through a mounting system or a mounting system is used to support the machine directly eliminating the foundation block, Figure 1(b) and (c) may be considered to be two degrees of freedom foundations. Figure 1.
Schematic of the closed high-speed press system. 1–nut, 2–main linkage, 3–inertia flywheel, 4–upper die, 5–lower beam, 6–mounting system, 7–column, 8–lower die, 9–slider, 10–upper beam, 11–crankshaft, 12–pull rod, 13–auxiliary linkage, 14–auxiliary slider.

The closed high-speed press has a pre-stressed gantry frame, with a crank-connecting rod mechanism in which the crankshaft is placed horizontally. The spindle has an eccentric shaft structure, one end connected to the flywheel and clutch and the other to the motor. Rotation is produced by the motor and is slowed down by the belt to pass through the slider via the connecting rod and translates into linear motion, which causes the slider to reciprocate up and down inside the track and produce the punching force. In order to ensure forming accuracy, the auxiliary slider mechanism is designed as dynamic balance components.

During the working process, the striking force and unbalanced inertia force of moving components such as slider and upper die in the closed high-speed press cause the frame and base to vibrate; however, the unbalanced inertia force of closed high-speed press is minor enough to be ignored due to the dynamic balance components. The crankshaft, connecting-rod and column of the press undergo elastic deformation and accumulate a certain amount of elastic energy. After the pressing ceases, there is a potential energy release due to the sudden loss of striking force, which causes the upper and lower frame of the press to vibrate. Therefore, the components of the upper half column and upper beam of the closed high-speed press, the lower half column and lower beam of the press can be seen as two rigid mass points.

sec.title: Foundation stiffness and damping
sec.p: The foundation impedance of the press can be determined using the analytical and numerical approaches to solve a mixed boundary-value problem in elastokinetics, and is generally function of soil properties, foundation type and size, and exciting frequency.

A number of analytical and numerical approaches, mostly based on the assumption of elastic or viscoelastic soil continuum, can be used to calculate the impedance functions for both shallow and deep foundation systems. The impedance function of a foundation system is a complex quantity that has a real part that represents the stiffness and an imaginary (out-of-phase) component that represents the damping. The impedance function of the foundation in the vertical direction can be written as2 (1)K=k+iωc where k is the stiffness constant, c is the constant of equivalent viscous damping and ω is the vibration frequency in rad/s.

sec.title: Foundation on soil
sec.p:
For embedded foundations in a deep homogeneous stratum, the stiffness and damping constants can be calculated using the formulae in Beredugo and Novak16 and Novak,17 i.e. (2)k=Gr0(Cυ1+GsGlr0Sυ1),c=r02ρG(C¯υ2+S¯υ2lr0ρsρGsG) where G is the soil shear modulus, r0 the base radius for circular bases or the equivalent radius (A/π) for non-circular bases, ρ the soil density, l the embedment depth, and Gs and ρs the shear modulus and density of the side layers (backfill). The dimensionless stiffness and damping parameters Cυ1 and C¯υ2 depend on the dimensionless frequency a0=ω0r0/Vs where ω0 is the system natural frequency and Vs is the soil shear wave velocity. Sυ1 and S¯υ2 are the dimensionless stiffness and damping parameters for the side layer. The values of Cυ1,C¯υ2,Sυ1andS¯υ2 that are suitable for most press applications were provided by Novak,3 and are presented in Table 1. Table 1.
Practical stiffness and damping parameters for hammer foundations.
Soil Half space (deep stratum) Side layer
Cv1 C¯v2 Sv1 S¯v2
Cohesive 7.5 6.8 2.7 6.7
Granular 5.2 5.0

sec.title: Foundation on piles
sec.p: The stiffness and damping of pile foundations are evaluated from the stiffness and damping of single piles modified to account for the group effect. The vertical stiffness and damping coefficients for a single pile can be calculated as17 (3)k=EpApRfυ1, c=EpApVsfυ2 where Ep, Ap and R are the Young’s modulus, cross-sectional area and radius of the pile, respectively. The dimensionless parameters fυ1 and fυ2 represent the soil properties and are given in charts in Novak.18 The stiffness and damping of a group of piles can be computed using the approach described in El Naggar and Novak.19 In this approach, the stiffness and damping of single piles are calculated first, then the group effect is accounted for using the dynamic interaction factors introduced in Kaynia and Kausel.20

sec.title: Press on mounting systems
sec.p: Mounting systems for closed high-speed presses can be either pads of viscoelastic material such as cork, hard felt or rubber, or sets of springs and dampers arranged in a parallel manner. If a viscoelastic pad is used, the dynamic characteristics of the mounting system can be computed knowing its dimensions and material properties. The vertical stiffness and damping of the pad can be expressed as (4)k=EpApd, c=tanδpkω0 where Ep is the Young’s modulus of the pad material, Ap and d are the cross-sectional area and the thickness of the pad, tanδp is the pad material damping ratio and ω0 is the natural frequency expressed in radians per second. The stiffness and damping constants of mounting systems that have springs and viscous dampers depend on the materials they are made of and their configurations are usually supplied by the manufacturer.

sec.title: Traditional dynamic model
sec.p:
Hammer and press foundations are often modelled as lumped mass system. Based on the configuration of the foundation (Figure 1(b) and (c)), traditional press with a mounting system is usually modelled as a two-mass system,1 as shown in Figure 2, where ma is the mass of the machine and mb is the mass of foundation block, the spring Ka and dashpot Ca represent the mounting system and the spring Kb and dashpot Cb represent the stiffness and damping of the foundation system that can be evaluated using the procedure described previously. The dynamic load p(t) due to the normal operation of the machine usually lasts a few milliseconds. Finally, va and vb are the responses of the closed high-speed press and the foundation block, respectively. Figure 2.
Traditional dynamic model of press system.

sec.title: Innovative dynamic model
sec.p:
The innovative lumped parameter model of closed high-speed press with mounting system (Figure 1(b) and (c)) is suggested, as shown in Figure 3. The model reflects the interaction of all major components of the press and also the interaction of system with its surroundings. The vibrations of the high-speed press that are observed in the vertical direction are the most significant, and it is the impact force, resulting from the collision between upper die and lower die, is considered to be the major factor that is responsible for vibration. Figure 3.
Innovative dynamic model of closed high-speed press system.

It is assumed that the treated materials are restored before each new impact, the process of penetration into the materials is not taken into account. Consequently, the object being treated can be represented as a linear spring-damper combination.
Equations of motion of each mass take the general form (7)mix··i=∑Fiimp+∑Fiel where ∑Fiimp is the sum of impact forces applied to the mass, ∑Fiel is the sum of elasticity forces applied to the mass.

The model of viscoelastic impact, which relies on the Kelvin-Voigt model,21–23 was used as the basis for a description of the collisions between the parts of the closed high-speed press. The limiter was modelled as a parallel spring and dashpot and the impact force was calculated using the formula24 (8)Fiimp(zi,z·i)={ciz·i+kizizi>0,Fiimp(zi,z·i)>00zi>0,Fiimp(zi,z·i)≤0 0zi<0 where zi is the contact deformation. To illustrate, F3imp is the impact force between the upper die and the lower die, and z3=x3-d-x8, where x3 and x8 are relative displacements of the masses m3 and m8 from their equilibrium position, d is the stroke length of upper die (when all elastic elements are not deformed, the slider is at the extreme distance).

In a similar manner (9)Fiel=ciz·i+kizi The impact force applied to the slider-crank mechanism with balance components is shown in Figure 4. The angular velocity ω is a constant, and from Figure 4, it can be seen that the reaction force due to the rigid coupling between the crank and bearing supports of the closed high-speed press is transferred to the upper beam of the press. In this case, only vibration in the vertical direction is considered. As a result (10)F01=m1a1cosα+m1g+FA1+FA2λ1sinα +m4g-m4a4cosα+FE1λ2sinα-FE2 Figure 4.
Motion sketch of crank-slider mechanism with balance components.

The above set of equations of motions (5)–(10) for the proposed model can be used to investigate the combined frame of the press since they include all the major parts of the press system and their mutual interactions; however, the non-linearity and complexity of the model make analytical solutions difficult, hence the model was investigated numerically.

sec.title: Method of analysis
sec.p: A set of state variables selected for analysis are listed below (11){u1=x7u2=x8u3=x9u4=x·7u5=x·8u6=x·9
The dynamic equations can be rewritten as (12){m7x··7+k7(x7-x8)+c7(x·7-x·8)=-F01m8x··8+k8(x8-x9)+c8(x·8-x·9)+k7(x8-x7) +c7(x·8-x·7)=F3impm9x··9+k8(x9-x8)+c8(x·9-x·8)+k9x9+c9x·9=0

Results from the above yield the first-order differential equations (13){u·1=u4u·2=u5u·3=u6u·4=-k7m7u1+k7m7u2-c7m7u4+c7m7u5-1m7F01u·5=k7m8u1-k7+k8m8u2+k8m8u3+c7m8u4-c7+c8m8u5 +c8m8u6+1m8F3impu·6=k8m9u2-k8+k9m9u3+c8m9u5-c8+c9m9u6 and equation (13) above can also be expressed in the matrix form (14)[u·1u·2u·3u·4u·5u·6]=[000100000010000001-k7m7k7m70-c7m7c7m70k7m8-k7+k8m8k8m8c7m8-c7+c8m8c8m80k8m9-k8+k9m90c8m9-c8+c9m9] ×[u1u2u3u4u5u6]+[000-F01m7F3impm80]

Due to the introduction of the state vector, the second-order differential equations reduce to the first-order differential equations, which permit easy mathematical handling. Numerical solutions with higher precision can be achieved using the fourth-order Runge–Kutta method.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p: Piling working conditions for closed high-speed presses are generally used during the process of factory inspection and test after the press products have been manufactured. Here, the JF75G-200 closed high-speed press under piling working condition is taken as a numerical example, which is installed on a mounting system similar to the foundation system shown in Figure 1(c).

The foundation is square and the foundation is fully embedded in the soil. The average shear wave velocity of the soil is 150 m/s and its mass density is 1900 kg/m3. The total mass of the foundation is 400,000 kg. The average shear wave velocity of the backfill material is 120 m/s and the mass density is 2400 kg/m3. The soil shear modulus can be evaluated as G=ρVs2 and is equal to 42.75 MPa for the stratum and 25.9 MPa for the side layers. Therefore, the stiffness and damping constants of the foundation can be calculated using equation (2) k=8.11×108N/m,c=1.13×107N/m/s

As the structure of the combined frame is very complex, FEM is used to obtain its stiffness. A three-dimensional solid element, SOLID45, is defined as the element type for meshing. The material properties of each component for combined frame are listed in Table 2. With a boundary constraint applied to one end of the FE model according to the real system condition, and a certain static force applied to the other end, then the FE results are obtained and shown in Figure 5. Figure 5.
Deformation results of FE calculation: (a) pull rod, (b) column, (c) upper beam. Table 2.
Material properties of combined frame.
Property Young’s modulus (Pa) Poisson’s ratio Density (kg/m3)
Upper beam 2.1×1011 0.3 7850
Bearing seat 2.1×1011 0.26 7850
Column 1.5×1011 0.25 7000
Pull rod 2.1×1011 0.28 7850
Lower beam 1.2×1011 0.25 7000
Base 1.2×1011 0.25 7000

Based on the FE results, as shown in Figure 6, the stiffness of pull rod, column and upper beam can be given by Klg=FΔl=100N0.321×10-4mm=3.12×109N/m Kz=FΔl=400N0.237×10-4mm=16.9×109N/m Ksh=FΔl=60N0.188×10-5mm=32×109N/m Figure 6.
Dynamic response of combined frame: (a) acceleration, (b) velocity.

Then, substituting the stiffness of pull rod, column and upper beam into equation (B1) and the stiffness of combined frame can be obtained k=2klz×ksh2klz+ksh+4klg=2×16.9×322×16.9+32+4×3.12=29.08×109N/m

Similarly, to obtain the damping ratio of combined frame, the vibration response amplitude of the combined frame under free vibration can be obtained using FEM as a result of its complex structure. When the base is fixed and an impulse load (the amplitude is 1 MN, and the duration time is 0.02 s) is applied to the worktable and bearing seats separately, the vibration acceleration responses from three different measuring points of the column under free vibration condition are obtained. The three date sets with smooth waveform and clear vibration amplitude for every 10 cycles are shown in Table 3. Table 3.
Vibration amplitude, logarithmic decrement rate and damping ratio.
Location Vibration amplitude (m/s2) Logarithmic decrement rateδ Damping ratioξ
x··i x··i+10T
1 5.56 1.32 0.1438 0.02288
2 5.47 1.39 0.137 0.0218
3 6.34 1.88 0.1216 0.02123
The damping ratio of combined frame is 0.02 approximately, as shown in Table 3, and the damping of combined frame can be calculated from equation (B5).

The parameters of the dynamic model for closed high-speed press are listed in Table 4. When the structural parameters in Table 4 are substituted into equation (6), the vibration acceleration and velocity curves of combined frame using traditional dynamic model with a rotation speed of 240 rpm under piling working condition is produced (Figure 6). Table 4.
Structural parameters of dynamic model.
Parameter Value Parameter Value Parameter Value
LF 310 mm m2 270 kg k7 29.08 × 109 N/m
LC 412 mm m3 2180 kg k8 6.74 × 106 N/m
L1 485 mm m4 19 kg k9 8.11 × 108 N/m
L2 460 mm m5 70 kg k10 1.21 × 1010 N/m
R1 15 mm m6 1360 kg c7 7.87 × 105 N/m/s
R2 25 mm m7 13,300 kg c8 1.12 × 105 N/m/s
d 29.9 mm m8 11,583 kg c9 1.13 × 107 N/m/s
m1 38 kg m9 4000 kg c10 2.87 × 105 N/m/s

As can be seen from Figure 6, the single peak value of the theoretical vibration acceleration of combined frame is about 40.8 m/s2 within a striking cycle of 0.25 s and the peak-peak value is 48.38 m/s2, while the single peak and peak-peak values of velocity are 35.19 mm/s and 42.35 mm/s.

The structural parameters in Table 4 are substituted into equation (14) to obtain the theoretical and experimental vibration acceleration curves of the upper and lower beams of the closed high-speed press with a rotation speed of 240 rpm under piling working condition (Figures7 and 8). Figure 7.
Theoretical vibration acceleration: (a) upper beam, (b) lower beam. Figure 8.
Experimental vibration acceleration: (a) upper beam, (b) lower beam.

As shown in Figure 7, the single peak value of the theoretical vibration acceleration of the upper beam is about 93 m/s2 within a striking cycle of 0.25 s and the peak-peak value is about 180 m/s2, while the values for the lower beam are around 110 and 214 m/s2, respectively. The experimental vibration acceleration curves of the upper and lower beams are shown in Figure 8. The experimental single peak value and the peak-peak value of the vibration acceleration of the upper beam are about 86 and 165 m/s2, and those of the lower beam are around 96 and 192 m/s2. As revealed by the experimental vibration acceleration curves, the interval between the previous and the next acceleration impact peaks is about 0.25 s, matching the striking cycle. The single peak error between the theoretical and experimental vibration acceleration curves of the upper beam is about 8.1% and the peak-peak error is approximately 9%, and those of the lower beam are around 14.58% and 11.45%, respectively. In addition to verify the model through the maximum value, a comparison between theoretical and experimental vibration acceleration is made at selected typical time in a single period (Table 5). The theoretical results depend on several empirical parameters, such as damping and foundation related parameters, which could have been a source of errors between the theoretical and experimental values. However, it is apparent that the theoretical results from the proposed dynamic model given in this work are more consistent with the experimental data than results obtained using a traditional dynamic model, which verifies the validity of the proposed dynamic model. Table 5.
Comparison between theoretical and experimental vibration acceleration.
Time (s) Vibration acceleration of upper beam (m/s2) Vibration acceleration of lower beam (m/s2)
Theoretical Experimental Error (%) Theoretical Experimental Error (%)

The theoretical and experimental vibration acceleration peak-peak value curves of the upper and lower beams of the closed high-speed press at different speeds of rotation are shown in Figures 9 and 10. Figure 9.
Theoretical (◊) and experimental (□) vibration acceleration of the upper beam. Figure 10.
Theoretical (◊) and experimental (□) vibration acceleration of the lower beam.

From Figure 9 it can be seen that the vibration acceleration curve of the upper beam descends with the increasing speed of rotation. The theoretical acceleration is greater than the experimental, and, as the speed keeps going up, errors between the theoretical results and the experimental results increase. In contrast, the vibration acceleration curve of the lower beam increases with increasing rotation speed (Figure 10), while the errors between the theoretical and experimental acceleration results increase.

The theoretical and experimental vibration velocity curves of the upper and lower beams of the closed high-speed press with a rotation speed of 240 rpm under piling working condition are shown in Figures 11 and 12. Figure 11.
Theoretical vibration velocity: (a) upper beam, (b) lower beam. Figure 12.
Experimental vibration velocity: (a) upper beam, (b) lower beam.

As the theoretical vibration velocity curves of the upper and lower beams (Figure 11) reveal, the single-peak and peak-peak values of the upper beam’s vibration velocity are about 40 and 76 mm/s, and those of the lower beam’s are about 53 and 98 mm/s. It can be seen from Figure 12 that the single-peak and peak-peak values of the upper beam’s experimental vibration velocity are around 39 and 69 mm/s, and those of the lower beam’s are approximately 54 and 100 mm/s. The single peak error between the theoretical and experimental vibration velocity of the upper beam is about 2.56% and the peak-peak error approximately 10.14%, those of the lower beam are around 1.85% and 2%. In addition to verify the model using the maximum value, a comparison is made between the theoretical and experimental vibration velocities at selected typical time in a single period (Table 6). It is apparent that the theoretical results from the proposed dynamic model in this work are more consistent with the experimental data than results obtained from a traditional dynamic model, which also verifies the validity of the dynamic model. Table 6.
Comparison between theoretical and experimental vibration velocity.
Time (s) Vibration velocity of upper beam (mm/s) Vibration velocity of lower beam (mm/s)
Theoretical Experimental Error (%) Theoretical Experimental Error (%)
0.02 25.78 26.47 2.6 28.14 32.37 13.07
0.03 16.63 17.54 5.19 21.16 21.49 1.54

The theoretical and experimental peak-peak value curves of the upper and lower beams’ vibration velocity at different rotation speeds are shown in Figures 13 and 14. Figure 13.
Theoretical (◊) and experimental (□) vibration velocity of the upper beam. Figure 14.
Theoretical (◊) and experimental (□) vibration velocity of the lower beam.

From Figures 13 and 14 it can be seen that the vibration velocity of the upper beam decreases with increasing rotation speed, but it also has a nearly linear relationship, while the errors between the theoretical and experimental velocities remain almost the same. The theoretical velocity is greater than the experimental data. In contrast, the vibration velocity of the lower beam increases with an increasing rotation speed and as the speed increase, the errors between the theoretical and experimental results continue to increase.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In this work, a novel dynamic model for the closed high-speed press system is developed to predict and evaluate its dynamic performance. Unlike in previous models where the press frame is considered to be a single mass and the effects of the transmission mechanism and complex frame structure are neglected, the present model allows us to analyze the dynamic response of a multi-body vibration-impact system treating it as a coupled one. The simulation results reveal that the dynamic responses of press under piling condition include a transient impact and a free vibration process. The vibration acceleration and velocity curves of the upper beam of the closed high-speed press decrease with the increasing speed of rotation. In contrast, vibration acceleration and velocity curves of the lower beam of the press increase with the increasing rotation speed. The experimental results demonstrate that the dynamic model proposed herein is consistent with the actual working state of the closed high-speed press and the validity of the dynamic model is verified.

Dynamic optimization design of the combined frame and the foundation system based on the proposed dynamic model should be pursued in the future. Because it is necessary to reduce the dynamic response of foundation (maximum allowable vibration amplitudes and the force transmitted to the soil), which is of great importance to reduce the physiological effects on the workers in the vicinity of the press and reduce any disturbance to nearby residential areas.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This article has been partially supported by the research projects: ‘Key Scientific and Technological Project’ (grant no. BE2006036) and ‘Jiangsu Fund Project for Transformation of Scientific and Technological Achievements’ (grant no. BA2008030).

normal acceleration and tangential acceleration at center of mass of auxiliary linkage
acceleration at mass center of auxiliary linkage and additional weight

damping of foundation and die

stiffness of foundation system and die
mass of main crank and linkage
mass of main slider and auxiliary crank
mass of auxiliary linkage and additional weight
the sum mass of upper beam, motor, large inertia flywheel, crankshaft, counterbalance slider, the upper half part of pull rods and columns, and the lower half part mass of pull rod and columns
the mass of foundation system and die
force of constraint of frame to crankshaft at hinge point O
force of main crank to main linkage
force of auxiliary crank to auxiliary linkage

distance from point C and point G to point B and point F
additional active torque on mechanism
distance from point D and point H to rotation center O
length of main crank OA and auxiliary crank OE
rotation angle between the crank and the slide way and between the linkage and the slide way

turning rate of point A relative to point B, point E relative to point F
turning rate of main crank and auxiliary crank

sec.title: Dynamics of crank-slider mechanism with balance components
sec.p: As the main and auxiliary crankshaft rotate with a constant angular velocity ω, the centripetal acceleration a1, a4 for mass center D of the main crankshaft and mass center H of the auxiliary crankshaft are expressed as (18)a1=RDω2,a4=RHω2

According to D’Alembert principle, the inertia force, active force and constraint force acting on a motion system form a balance force system and the force sketch of the crank-slider mechanism with balance components is shown in Figure 15 (all friction resistances are ignored). Figure 15.
Force sketch of crank-slider mechanism.

Firstly, by separating the main linkage, the force sketch of the main linkage is shown in Figure 16(a), in which FA1, FA2 are forces acting on the main linkage from the main crank shaft. According to the force balance relationship of the main linkage, FA1, FA2 can be obtained (19)FA1=(m2+m3)(g+a3)-P-m2a2n +m2a2τλ1(1-LCL1)sinα +λ12sin2α[(g+a3)(m2+m3-m2LCL1)-P]FA2=m2a2τLCL1+m2(a3+g)λ1LCL1sinα} Figure 16.
Force sketch of crank shaft and linkage: (a) main linkage, (b) auxiliary linkage, (c) main and auxiliary crank shaft.

Secondly, by separating the auxiliary linkage, the force sketch of the auxiliary linkage is shown in Figure 16(b), in which FE1, FE2 are forces acting on the auxiliary linkage from the auxiliary crank shaft. According to the force balance relationship of the auxiliary linkage, FE1, FE2 can be obtained (20)FE1=(m5+m6)(g-a6)+m5a5n +λ22sin2α(g-a6)(m5+m6-m5LFL2) -m5a5τλ2(1-LFL2)sinαFE2=m5a5τLFL2-m5(g-a6)λ2LFL2sinα}
Finally, by separating the main crankshaft and the auxiliary crankshaft, the force sketch of the main crankshaft and the auxiliary crankshaft is shown in Figure 16(c).

The reaction force due to the rigid coupling between the crank and upper beam of the closed high-speed press is transferred to the upper beam. In this case, only vibration in the vertical direction is considered. As a result (21)F01=m1a1cosα+m1g+FA1+FA2λ1sinα+m4g -m4a4cosα+FE1λ2sinα-FE2

sec.title: Stiffness and damping of combined frame
sec.p: The press can be described as the complex system composed of the upper and lower beams and columns that are connected by pull rods. According to the technical requirements of manufacturers, a two-fold nominal preload is imposed on the combined frame using the dedicated hydraulic preload devices. As revealed by the experiments on the columns’ stress and strain, surfaces between the columns and the upper and lower beams keep in full contact during the actual stamping process. Considering the structural characteristics of the closed combined frame of high-speed press, the stiffness of the frame can be determined by the following connections: connecting the two columns firstly in parallel and then in series with the upper and lower beams, and finally again in parallel with the four pull rods, composing the entire combined frame. Thus, the general equation for calculating the stiffness of closed preloaded combined frame can be written as (22)k=2klz×ksh2klz+ksh+4klg where klz, ksh and klg represent the stiffness of the column, the upper beam and the pull rod respectively.

The damping of the combined frame is one parameter that is difficult to determine accurately. To solve this problem, the logarithmic decrement rate δ of combined frame is determined above all by virtue of free vibration response. The logarithmic decrement rate δ of the combined frame is given by (23)δ=lnxixi+T=2πξ1-ξ2 where ξ is the damping ratio of the combined frame, xi the displacement amplitude on a certain location of the column when the time is at ti, xi+T the displacement amplitude on the same location of the column when the time is at ti+T, and T the period of free vibration response for the combined frame.

As the value of ξ is very small, the logarithmic decrement rate δ can also be written as (24)δ=lnxixi+T=2πξ In practice, n adjacent cycles are usually selected for calculating the logarithmic decrement rate δ. Then (25)δ=lnxixi+nT=n2πξ

In a similar manner, the logarithmic decrement rate δ can also be calculated from the vibration acceleration amplitude ratio of the combined frame under free vibration condition. Once the logarithmic decrement rate δ is determined, the damping ratio ξ and then obtain the damping of the combined frame can be given as follows (26)c=2ξmk
